From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]
English Wikipedia has an article on:
modifier
Wikipedia

Etymology

[edit]

From modify +‎ -er.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • (Received Pronunciation) IPA(key): /ˈmɒdɪfaɪə/
  • Audio (Southern England):(file)
  • (General American) IPA(key): /ˈmɑdɪfaɪɚ/
  • Hyphenation: mod‧i‧fi‧er

Noun

[edit]

modifier (plural modifiers)

  2. One who, or that which, modifies.
  4. (grammar) A word, phrase, or clause that limits or qualifies the sense of another word or phrase. (It may be any of the following: an adjective phrase, an adverb phrase, a prepositional phrase, a noun phrase, or a subordinate clause.)
    Synonym: qualifier
    Hypernym: adjunct
    Coordinate term: supplement
  6. (programming) A keyword that qualifies the meaning of other code.
    The protected modifier makes a class member visible to subclasses, but not to external code.
  8. (computing) Ellipsis of modifier key.

Synonyms

[edit]
  • qualifier

Derived terms

[edit]
  • access modifier
  • compound modifier
  • dangling modifier
  • immunomodifier
  • modifier key
  • noun modifier
  • small ubiquitin-related modifier
  • squinting modifier
  • submodifier

Related terms

[edit]
  • postmodifier
  • premodifier

Translations

[edit]
one who modifies
  • Bulgarian: модифика́тор m (modifikátor)
  • Catalan: modificador m
  • Finnish: muunnin, modifikaattori
  • French: modificateur (fr) m, modificateuse (fr) f
  • Galician: modificador m
  • German: Modifikator m, Modifikatorin f
  • Persian:
    Iranian Persian: اِصْلاحْگَر (fa) (eslâhgar)
  • Polish: modyfikator (pl) m
  • Portuguese: modificador (pt) m
  • Russian: модифика́тор (ru) m (modifikátor)
grammar: qualifying word, clause or phrase
  • Arabic: please add this translation if you can
  • Belarusian: азначэ́нне n (aznačénnje), азначэ́ньне n (aznačénʹnje)
  • Bulgarian: определе́ние (bg) n (opredelénie)
  • Chinese:
    Mandarin: 修飾語 / 修饰语 (zh) (xiūshìyǔ)
  • Czech: přívlastek (cs) m
  • Dutch: modificeerder m
  • Finnish: määrite (fi), määriteosa (fi)
  • French: modificateur (fr) m
  • German: Attribut (de) n, Bestimmungswort (de) n, Bestimmung (de) f
  • Hindi: विशेषण (hi) m (viśeṣaṇ)
  • Hungarian: jelző (hu), szabad bővítmény, jelzői vagy szabad határozói (szerepű) kifejezés
  • Japanese: 修飾語 (ja) (しゅうしょくご, shūshokugo), 修飾子 (しゅうしょくし, shūshokushi)
  • Korean: 수식어(修飾語) (ko) (susigeo)

    Bokmål: adledd (no) n
  • Persian:
    Iranian Persian: (please verify) وصفال
  • Polish: przydawka (pl) f
  • Portuguese: modificador (pt) m
  • Russian: определе́ние (ru) n (opredelénije)
  • Sanskrit: विशेषण (sa) m (viśeṣaṇa)
  • Slovak: prívlastok m
  • Slovene: prilastek (sl) m
  • Spanish: modificador (es) m
  • Swedish: attribut (sv) n
  • Ukrainian: озна́чення (uk) n (oznáčennja)

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Latin modificāre, from modus.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /mɔ.di.fje/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (France (Toulouse)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

modifier

  1. to change, modify

Conjugation

simple — modifie
/mɔ.di.fi/ 		— modifions
/mɔ.di.fjɔ̃/ 		modifiez
/mɔ.di.fje/ 		—
compound — simple imperative of avoir + past participle — simple imperative of avoir + past participle simple imperative of avoir + past participle —
1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).
